Token

public Token()
Creates a new -empty- Instance of a Token. This constructor should not be used.

See Also:
Token(java.lang.String), Token(java.lang.String, java.lang.String), Token(java.lang.String, java.lang.String, long), Token(java.lang.String, java.lang.String, long, java.lang.String), BearerToken, macToken

Token

public Token(java.lang.String token)
Creates a new Instance of a Token.
Every token has a String representing the token itself. It can contain letters, numbers or special characters.
Some token may contain more information than the token key, for example a secret to encrypt the token. Please see the service providers specifications to find a more suitable constructor.

Parameters:
token - String of the token itself
See Also:
Token(java.lang.String, java.lang.String), Token(java.lang.String, java.lang.String, long), Token(java.lang.String, java.lang.String, long, java.lang.String), BearerToken, macToken

Token

public Token(java.lang.String token,
             java.lang.String scope)
Creates a new Instance of a Token.
Every token has a String representing the token itself. It can contain letters, numbers or special characters. Depending on the service providers specification, a token may have a special scope of resources it can access. A scope is always represented by a series of concatenated strings seperated by a whitespace. There are no standards specified in the OAuth2.0 protocoll on how the scope of a token should be defined. Definition and range of a scope should be explained by the service provider.

Parameters:
token - String of the token itself
scope - String defining the scope of the token (optional - see service provider for details)
See Also:
Token(java.lang.String), Token(java.lang.String, java.lang.String, long), Token(java.lang.String, java.lang.String, long, java.lang.String), BearerToken, macToken

Token

public Token(java.lang.String token,
             java.lang.String scope,
             long secondsValid)
Creates a new Instance of a Token.
Every token has a String representing the token itself. It can contain letters, numbers or special characters. Depending on the service providers specification, a token may have a special scope of resources it can access. A scope is always represented by a series of concatenated strings seperated by a whitespace. There are no standards specified in the OAuth2.0 protocoll on how the scope of a token should be defined. Definition and range of a scope should be explained by the service provider.
Most tokens have a predefined lifetime, so that they are not valid for ever and the chances of abuse of the token can be limited.

Parameters:
token - String of the token itself
scope - String defining the scope of the token (optional - see service provider for details)
secondsValid - number of seconds the token will be valid (optional)
See Also:
Token(java.lang.String), Token(java.lang.String, java.lang.String), Token(java.lang.String, java.lang.String, long, java.lang.String), BearerToken, macToken

Token

public Token(java.lang.String token,
             java.lang.String scope,
             long secondsValid,
             java.lang.String type)
Creates a new Instance of a Token.
Every token has a String representing the token itself. It can contain letters, numbers or special characters. Depending on the service providers specification, a token may have a special scope of resources it can access. A scope is always represented by a series of concatenated strings seperated by a whitespace. There are no standards specified in the OAuth2.0 protocoll on how the scope of a token should be defined. Definition and range of a scope should be explained by the service provider.
Most tokens have a predefined lifetime, so that they are not valid for ever and the chances of abuse of the token can be limited.
It is possible to define, what kind of token is used. The standard type of a token is Bearer, there are however more types as for example MAC-Tokens or SAML-Bearer-Tokens. Defining the type of a token does not define the corresponding subclass of this token class. It is recommended to use an appropriate subclass or, if not implemented yet, define a new class, depending on the type of token the provider expects.

Parameters:
token - String of the token itself
scope - String defining the scope of the token (optional - see service provider for details)
secondsValid - number of seconds the token will be valid (optional)
See Also:
Token(java.lang.String), Token(java.lang.String, java.lang.String), Token(java.lang.String, java.lang.String, long), BearerToken, macToken

Token

public Token(java.io.FileInputStream fileInputStream)
      throws java.io.IOException,
             java.lang.ClassNotFoundException
Creates a new Token by reading a FileInputStream. If a token was searialized and saved into a file by using the Token classes method writeToFileOutputStream() or by using a similar method as for example serializing the Token object with ObjectOutputStream, this method can read the Token back from a FileInputStream.

Example:
saving a token:
FileOutputStream outputStream = new FileOutputStream("path/to/myFile");
myToken.writeToFileOutputStream(outputStream);

reading a token:
FileInputStream inputStream = new FileInputStream("path/to/myFile");
Token myToken = new Token(inputStream);

Parameters:
fileInputStream - inputStream from the file containing the token
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if an error occures while reading the inputStream
java.lang.ClassNotFoundException - if the stream does not contain a proper token
Method Detail

getToken

public java.lang.String getToken()
Returns the token string itself. This is only the key value of the token and is not related to the toString() method. Every token must have a key value otherwise the token is empty.

Returns:
key value of the token as a String

setToken

public void setToken(java.lang.String token)
Sets the key of a token. Every token MUST have a key, it is the tokens value itself. Without the key the token is empty.

Parameters:
token -

getSecondsValid

public long getSecondsValid()
Some tokens have a predefined lifetime, so that they are not valid for ever and the chances of abuse of the token can be limited. If the lifetime of the token was predefined this method returns the number of seconds the token was supposed to be valid. If the lifetime of the token is unlimited or no predefined lifetime was set a -1 is returned.
This is not the actual number of seconds the token is still valid. To determine if a token is still valid use the isValid() method.

Returns:
number of seconds this token was supposed to be valid.

setSecondsValid

public void setSecondsValid(long secondsValid)
Sets the number of seconds a token is supposed to be valid from the beginning of its creation. If no lifetime for the token was set, the default is 0. For an unlimited lifetime set the number of seconds to -1 (default);

Parameters:
secondsValid - number of seconds the token is valid

getCreated

public long getCreated()
Returns the creation time (seconds passed since January 1, 1970) This method is especially usefull when using the mac-token type and calculating the age of the token

Returns:
long time of creation in seconds

getScope

public java.lang.String getScope()
Returns alle scopes concatenated into one single string, sepperated by a whitespace character (according to the specifications)

Returns:
string concatenated scopes

setScope

public void setScope(java.lang.String scope)
To set the scope with one single string. Either it is only one scope or it containes many scopes seperated by a whitespace character (according to the specifications) [Facebook for example uses commas for seperating scopes] Any previously specified scope will be replaced by this string. To simply add a scope to the existing one use addScope(java.lang.String)

Parameters:
scope - string containing the scope
See Also:
#addScope(java.lang.String

addScope

public void addScope(java.lang.String scope)
Adds an additional scope at the end of the existing one. If no scope was set before a new scope will be created. All scopes will be seperated by a whitespace character (according to the specification).
If you are using facebook you might need to seperate the scopes with a comma and use setScope(java.lang.String) insetead. Please refere to your service providers api documentation.

Parameters:
scope - string with additional scope

getType

public java.lang.String getType()
Returns the type of the Token as a String. e.g. bearer or mac

Returns:
string naming the tokens type

setType

public void setType(java.lang.String type)
Sets the type of the Token. Normaly it should not be neccessary to call this method manualy, since the Response class detects wich type is used and sets this parameter automatically. (currently the bearer and the mac type are supported)

Parameters:
type -

getAdditionalParameters

public java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> getAdditionalParameters()

setAdditionalParameters

public void setAdditionalParameters(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> additionalParameters)

addAdditionalParameter

public void addAdditionalParameter(java.lang.String name,
                                   java.lang.String value)

isValid

public boolean isValid()
Determines if the token is still valid of if the predefined lifetime of the token since its creation has passed. This method will return true under the following circumstances:
i) the number of seconds passed since the creation of the token is smaller than or equal to the number of seconds the token was supposed to be valid.
ii) the number of seconds the token is supposed to be valid equals -1 (unlimited or undefined)

Returns:
true if token is still valid, if no lifetime was set or if lifetime is unlimited, false otherwise

toString

public java.lang.String toString()
Overrides:
toString in class java.lang.Object

writeToFileOutputStream

public void writeToFileOutputStream(java.io.FileOutputStream fileOutputStream)
                             throws java.io.IOException
Writes the token to the given FileOutputStream.
This method can be used in order to write Tokens into a file to store them for further usage. Especialy if this Token is a RefreshToken it should be saved until the current AccessToken is no longer valid.

Example:
saving a token:
FileOutputStream outputStream = new FileOutputStream("path/to/myFile");
myToken.writeToFileOutputStream(outputStream);

reading a token:
FileInputStream inputStream = new FileInputStream("path/to/myFile");
Token myToken = new Token(inputStream);

Parameters:
fileOutputStream - the Stream this Token should be written into.
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if an error occures while writing.

equals

public boolean equals(java.lang.Object object)

equals in class java.lang.Object
